question: 40 year old male with newly diagnosed moderate UC and articular extraintestinal manifestations
gt_reason: IFX is ideal choice as biologically naïve with EIM.
prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer: [{"drug_name": "Infliximab", "advantages": "Infliximab is an anti-TNF agent that has been shown to be effective in treating both ulcerative colitis and rheumatological manifestations, which is beneficial for this patient who has articular extraintestinal manifestations. It has a well-established efficacy supported by multiple trials.", "disadvantages": "Infliximab is administered via intravenous infusion, which may be inconvenient for some patients. There is also a risk of developing antibodies against infliximab, which can reduce its effectiveness over time. Side effects can include infections, allergic reactions, and potential liver damage."}, {"drug_name": "Adalimumab", "advantages": "Adalimumab is another anti-TNF agent that can be effective in treating both UC and rheumatological manifestations. It is administered via subcutaneous injection, which can be done at home, providing convenience for the patient.", "disadvantages": "Adalimumab may not work for everyone and some patients may develop antibodies against it, reducing its effectiveness. Side effects can include infections, allergic reactions, and potential liver damage."}]
pro1: Infliximab is an anti-TNF agent that has been shown to be effective in treating both ulcerative colitis and rheumatological manifestations, which is beneficial for this patient who has articular extraintestinal manifestations. It has a well-established efficacy supported by multiple trials.
cons1: Infliximab is administered via intravenous infusion, which may be inconvenient for some patients. There is also a risk of developing antibodies against infliximab, which can reduce its effectiveness over time. Side effects can include infections, allergic reactions, and potential liver damage.
pro2: Adalimumab is another anti-TNF agent that can be effective in treating both UC and rheumatological manifestations. It is administered via subcutaneous injection, which can be done at home, providing convenience for the patient.
cons2: Adalimumab may not work for everyone and some patients may develop antibodies against it, reducing its effectiveness. Side effects can include infections, allergic reactions, and potential liver damage.

Extraintestinal manifestations occur in half of IBD patients and
represent an important cause of morbidity and disability (Vavricka et al.,
2011; Juillerat et al., 2020). Among EIMs, articular manifestations affect
30% of patients. They include non-inﬂammatory joint pain as well as
inﬂammatory joint manifestations including axial arthritis considered as
spondyloarthropathies. Since their approval in IBD, inﬂiximab and later
the other anti-TNF agents represent the best treatment choice in IBD
patient with rheumatological manifestations, supported by multiple trials
in both CD and UC, in addition to their well-established efﬁcacies in most
rheumatological indications (Herfarth et al., 2002; Generini et al., 2004;
Lofberg et al., 2012; Louis et al., 2018).
Vedolizumab may not represent the most appropriate biologic in
presence of articular manifestations of IBD. Indeed, by virtue of its

text: Burr et al.

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

question: 70 year old female with newly diagnosed severe UC
gt_reason: Given advanced age, IFX not preferred as first choice
prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================

- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age

- Pouchitis

Human: question
pro1: Infliximab is a biologic that targets tumor necrosis alpha (TNFi), which is involved in the inflammatory process of UC. It has been used for over 20 years and has shown efficacy in treating moderate to severe UC. It can lead to remission and reduce the need for hospitalization and surgery.
cons1: Infliximab is administered via infusion, which may not be convenient for all patients. It can also lead to side effects such as increased risk of infections. Some patients may develop antibodies to infliximab, leading to a loss of response over time.
pro2: Vedolizumab is a biologic that targets the integrin molecules involved in the inflammation process of UC. It has shown efficacy in treating moderate to severe UC and can lead to remission. Unlike TNFi biologics, it is gut-specific and does not suppress the entire immune system, potentially leading to fewer side effects.
cons2: Vedolizumab is also administered via infusion, which may not be convenient for all patients. It may take longer to see the effects of vedolizumab compared to TNFi biologics. Some patients may not respond to vedolizumab treatment.

question: 35 year old male with known moderate UC with prior exposure to infliximab but has worsening colitis on endoscopy despite compliance
gt_reason: Testing 2nd line treatment to patients previously exposed to anti-TNFa
prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the patient has moderate ulcerative colitis and has been previously treated with infliximab but is not responding well as evidenced by worsening colitis on endoscopy. Therefore, the patient falls under the category of those with prior exposure to TNF antagonists. 

Given this, the top two choices of biological drugs for this patient would be:

1. Ustekinumab
2. Tofacitinib

Here are the pros and cons of these two choices:

Ustekinumab:
- Advantages: Ustekinumab has been ranked highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement. It also has a lower risk of infections compared to other drugs.
- Disadvantages: The main disadvantage of ustekinumab is that it may not be as effective as other drugs in patients who are biologic-naive. 

Tofacitinib:
- Advantages: Tofacitinib is also ranked highly in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement. It can be administered orally and on a daily basis, which may be more convenient for some patients.
- Disadvantages: The main disadvantage of tofacitinib is that it may have a higher risk of infections compared to other drugs.

Please note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances and preferences, and in consultation with their healthcare provider.

pro1: Ranked highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement, lower risk of infections
cons1: May not be as effective in patients who are biologic-naive
pro2: Ranked highly in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement, can be administered orally and on a daily basis
cons2: May have a higher risk of infections

Studies had to recruit ambulatory adults (≥18 years) with moderate to severely active UC 
(Supplementary Table 1), and compared biological therapies or small molecules with 
placebo, or with each other. We required a minimum follow-up duration of 6 weeks.  
Two investigators (NEB and ACF) conducted independent literature searches. We 
identified studies on UC with the terms: inflammatory bowel disease, colitis, or ulcerative 
colitis (both as medical subject headings and free text terms). We combined these using the 
set operator AND with studies identified with the following terms: infliximab, remicade,

source3:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1.0

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.
2180 Singh et al
Clinical Gastroenterology and Hepatology Vol. 18, No. 10
source4:
title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 5.0

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

text: Burr et al. 
 
8 of 45 
In the last 10 years small molecules, which can be administered orally and on a daily 
basis, have also been evaluated in moderate to severe UC. These include janus kinase 
inhibitors, such as tofacitinib,[20] and the sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor modulator, 
ozanimod.[21] The comparative efficacy and safety of all these drugs has been assessed in 
prior network meta-analyses.[22, 23] These demonstrated that infliximab was ranked highest 
overall for efficacy, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked highest in patients with 
previous anti-TNF-α exposure. However, this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already 
several newer drugs that have shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not 
considered in these network meta-analyses.[24-26] We have therefore performed an updated 
network meta-analysis to evaluate the efficacy of all biological therapies and small molecules

In a systematic review and network meta-analysis, we found inﬂiximab to be ranked highest in

question: 60 year old female with newly diagnosed moderate UC with a background of congestive cardiac failure
gt_reason: Testing contraindications to first line IFX. TFC not recommended because of increased LDL-C and MACE risk
prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Vedolizumab and Adalimumab. 

1. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets inflammation in the gut, reducing systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe UC. It is also less likely to cause serious infections compared to other biologics.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may take longer to show effects compared to other biologics. It is administered via intravenous infusion, which may not be convenient for all patients. There is also a risk of infusion-related reactions.

2. Adalimumab:
   - Advantages: Adalimumab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe UC. It is administered via subcutaneous injection, which can be done at home.
   - Disadvantages: Adalimumab can increase the risk of serious infections and may not be suitable for patients with a history of recurrent infections. It can also cause allergic reactions and other side effects like headache, rash, and nausea.

It's important to note that the patient's congestive cardiac failure should be taken into consideration when choosing a treatment, as some medications may exacerbate this condition. The patient's overall health status and preferences should also be considered.

text: Burr et al. 
 
7 of 45 
INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

incidence ranges from 9 to 20 cases per 100 000 per year with 
higher incidence in North America and Northern Europe.1
The advanced therapeutic armamentarium for adults 
with moderately to severely active UC is rapidly evolving. 
For over 20 years, biologics targeting specific inflamma-
tory pathways have been the mainstay, beginning with those 
targeting tumor necrosis alpha (TNFi; eg, infliximab [INF], 
adalimumab [ADA], and golimumab [GOL]) followed by 
biologics with other modes of action (eg, vedolizumab [VED] 
and ustekinumab [UST]). However, treatment limitations for 
moderately to severely active UC remain, including primary 
nonresponse, secondary loss of response, immunogenicity, and 
parenteral administration.2 To overcome these limitations, 
there has been increasing interest in small molecule drugs 
(SMDs), which can be orally administered and lack immu-
nogenicity.3 Of particular interest are SMDs that inhibit the

question: 38 year old female with newly diagnosed moderate UC and psoriasis
gt_reason: Test treatment of specific EIM and IBD
prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Ustekinumab (UST) and Vedolizumab (VDZ).

1. Ustekinumab (UST)
   - Advantages: UST is an anti-interleukin-12/23 antibody that has shown efficacy in treating both UC and psoriasis, which is an extraintestinal manifestation present in this patient. It can be a good choice for patients with both conditions.
   - Disadvantages: As with any medication, there can be side effects. These can include respiratory infections, fatigue, headache, and injection site reactions. There is also a risk of serious infections, malignancies, and hypersensitivity reactions.

2. Vedolizumab (VDZ)
   - Advantages: VDZ is an anti-integrin antibody that has shown efficacy in treating moderate to severe UC. It is generally well tolerated and has a good safety profile.
   - Disadvantages: While VDZ is effective for UC, it may not address the patient's psoriasis. Also, it may take longer to see the effects of VDZ compared to other treatments. Side effects can include headache, joint pain, nausea, and fever. There is also a risk of serious infections.

Please note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's overall health, lifestyle, and personal preferences. It is also important to monitor the patient's response to treatment and adjust as necessary.

title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 8.0

text: Burr et al. 
 
8 of 45 
In the last 10 years small molecules, which can be administered orally and on a daily 
basis, have also been evaluated in moderate to severe UC. These include janus kinase 
inhibitors, such as tofacitinib,[20] and the sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor modulator, 
ozanimod.[21] The comparative efficacy and safety of all these drugs has been assessed in 
prior network meta-analyses.[22, 23] These demonstrated that infliximab was ranked highest 
overall for efficacy, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked highest in patients with 
previous anti-TNF-α exposure. However, this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already 
several newer drugs that have shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not 
considered in these network meta-analyses.[24-26] We have therefore performed an updated 
network meta-analysis to evaluate the efficacy of all biological therapies and small molecules

Human: question
pro1: Infliximab is a well-studied and effective treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It has been shown to induce and maintain remission, promote mucosal healing, and improve quality of life. Infliximab is also considered safe for use during pregnancy, as it has a low risk of causing birth defects or complications.
cons1: Infliximab requires intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient. It can also cause side effects such as infections, allergic reactions, and liver damage. There is also a risk of developing antibodies against infliximab, which can reduce its effectiveness.
pro2: Adalimumab is another effective treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is administered via subcutaneous injection, which can be done at home. Adalimumab is also considered safe for use during pregnancy.
cons2: Adalimumab can cause side effects such as infections, allergic reactions, and liver damage. There is also a risk of developing antibodies against adalimumab, which can reduce its effectiveness. Additionally, it may not be as effective as infliximab in inducing remission.

disease extension occurred in 23% of patients at 7 years of

risk of surgery for CD and UC can be up to 46.6% and 15.6%
10 years after diagnosis, respectively, and has decreased
signiﬁcantly during the last 6 decades.14

Introduction 
Ulcerative colitis is a chronic, idiopathic, potentially 
disabling condition that is clinically characterised 
by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1 
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the 
third and fifth decades of life, and is associated with an 
impaired health-related quality of life and considerable 
economic burden.2,3
Nearly 20 years ago, the advent of anti-tumour necrosis 
factor biologics (eg, infliximab, adalimumab, and 
golimumab) revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative 
colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of 
increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, 
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality 
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved 
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,

gt_reason: Dual indications

- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Infliximab and Adalimumab. Both drugs are anti-TNF agents, which are effective in treating both ulcerative colitis and ankylosing spondylitis.

1. Infliximab:
   - Advantages: Infliximab is a potent anti-inflammatory drug that can induce and maintain remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also effective in treating ankylosing spondylitis. Infliximab has a rapid onset of action and can lead to symptom relief within a few weeks.
   - Disadvantages: Infliximab is administered via intravenous infusion, which can be inconvenient for some patients. It can also cause side effects such as infections, allergic reactions, and liver damage. There is also a risk of developing antibodies against infliximab, which can reduce its effectiveness.

2. Adalimumab:
   - Advantages: Adalimumab is also effective in treating both ulcerative colitis and ankylosing spondylitis. It is administered via subcutaneous injection, which can be done at home, providing convenience for the patient.
   - Disadvantages: Adalimumab may take longer to work compared to infliximab. It can also cause side effects such as infections, allergic reactions, and liver damage. Similar to infliximab, there is a risk of developing antibodies against adalimumab, which can reduce its effectiveness.

It's important to note that the choice between these two drugs should be individualized based on the patient's preferences, lifestyle, and overall health status. The patient should also be closely monitored for any side effects during the treatment.

incidence ranges from 9 to 20 cases per 100 000 per year with 
higher incidence in North America and Northern Europe.1
The advanced therapeutic armamentarium for adults 
with moderately to severely active UC is rapidly evolving. 
For over 20 years, biologics targeting specific inflamma-
tory pathways have been the mainstay, beginning with those 
targeting tumor necrosis alpha (TNFi; eg, infliximab [INF], 
adalimumab [ADA], and golimumab [GOL]) followed by 
biologics with other modes of action (eg, vedolizumab [VED] 
and ustekinumab [UST]). However, treatment limitations for 
moderately to severely active UC remain, including primary 
nonresponse, secondary loss of response, immunogenicity, and 
parenteral administration.2 To overcome these limitations, 
there has been increasing interest in small molecule drugs 
(SMDs), which can be orally administered and lack immu-
nogenicity.3 Of particular interest are SMDs that inhibit the

title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Vedolizumab and Ustekinumab. 

1. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets the gut and has less systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also a good option for patients who have a history of malignancy like this patient as it has a lower risk of reactivating latent malignancies compared to other biologics.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may take longer to work compared to other biologics. It also requires intravenous administration which can be inconvenient for some patients. 

2. Ustekinumab:
   - Advantages: Ustekinumab is a biologic that targets interleukin-12 and interleukin-23, key cytokines involved in inflammatory and immune responses. It has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also a good option for patients with a history of malignancy as it has a lower risk of reactivating latent malignancies.
   - Disadvantages: Ustekinumab requires an initial intravenous infusion followed by subcutaneous injections, which can be inconvenient for some patients. It may also be less effective in patients who have previously failed anti-TNF therapy. 

Please note that the choice of therapy should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances and preferences, and in consultation with their healthcare provider.

System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be:

1. Upadacitinib
2. Vedolizumab

[{"drug_name": "Upadacitinib", "advantages": "Upadacitinib has been shown to be highly efficacious in treating moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis. It has a similar safety profile across advanced therapies.", "disadvantages": "However, it was ranked highest for all adverse events in a study, and caution is advised when considering JAK inhibitors as treatment options, especially in patients with known risk factors for thrombosis."},

{"drug_name": "Vedolizumab", "advantages": "Vedolizumab is an anti-integrin antibody that has been approved for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis. It has a different mechanism of action compared to JAK inhibitors, which might be beneficial if the patient has not responded well to other treatments.", "disadvantages": "The effectiveness of Vedolizumab can vary between individuals, and it may not be as effective as other treatments like Upadacitinib. It also requires intravenous administration, which can be less convenient than oral medications."}]
pro1: Upadacitinib has been shown to be highly efficacious in treating moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis. It has a similar safety profile across advanced therapies.
cons1: However, it was ranked highest for all adverse events in a study, and caution is advised when considering JAK inhibitors as treatment options, especially in patients with known risk factors for thrombosis.
pro2: Vedolizumab is an anti-integrin antibody that has been approved for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis. It has a different mechanism of action compared to JAK inhibitors, which might be beneficial if the patient has not responded well to other treatments.
cons2: The effectiveness of Vedolizumab can vary between individuals, and it may not be as effective as other treatments like Upadacitinib. It also requires intravenous administration, which can be less convenient than oral medications.

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

Introduction 
Ulcerative colitis is a chronic, idiopathic, potentially 
disabling condition that is clinically characterised 
by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1 
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the 
third and fifth decades of life, and is associated with an 
impaired health-related quality of life and considerable 
economic burden.2,3
Nearly 20 years ago, the advent of anti-tumour necrosis 
factor biologics (eg, infliximab, adalimumab, and 
golimumab) revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative 
colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of 
increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, 
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality 
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved 
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,

question: 39 year-old male with moderate to severe extensive ulcerative colitis who had malignant melanoma which was treated 3 years ago
gt_reason: Anti-TNFs and JAK inhs have associations/concerns with malignancies
prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the patient is under maintenance for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and has a history of malignant melanoma. The patient's age is also a factor to consider in the treatment plan. However, the patient's prior response to Infliximab, prior failure to Anti-TNF agents, prior failure to Vedolizumab, pregnancy status, extraintestinal manifestations, and pouchitis are not mentioned in the profile.

Given this, two potential biological drugs that could be considered are:

1. Adalimumab
   - Advantages: Adalimumab is a TNF inhibitor that can help control symptoms and achieve remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It can be administered at home and does not require intravenous infusion.
   - Disadvantages: Adalimumab may increase the risk of serious infections and malignancies. Given the patient's history of malignant melanoma, this risk should be carefully considered. Regular monitoring for skin cancer is recommended.

2. Vedolizumab
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets inflammation in the gut, potentially causing fewer systemic side effects. It may be a suitable option for patients who have not responded to or cannot tolerate TNF inhibitors.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab requires intravenous infusion, which can be less convenient than self-administered injections. The risk of infection is also a concern, although it may be lower than with TNF inhibitors.

Please note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances, including disease severity, comorbidities, lifestyle, and personal preferences. The patient should be closely monitored for any potential side effects, particularly given his history of malignant melanoma.

title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 5.0

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

Human: question
pro1: Vedolizumab has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It specifically targets the gut, reducing systemic side effects. It has also been shown to have a lower risk of infections compared to other treatments.
cons1: Vedolizumab requires intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient for some patients. Some patients may also experience side effects such as headache, joint pain, nausea, or fever.
pro2: Adalimumab is a TNF inhibitor that can be used as a maintenance therapy for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is administered subcutaneously, which may be more convenient for some patients.
cons2: Adalimumab may not be as effective as vedolizumab in maintaining remission in some patients. It also carries a risk of serious infections and other side effects such as rash, nausea, and headaches.

METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the patient has moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and has developed a loss of response to Infliximab due to antibody formation. This suggests that the patient has had a prior failure to Anti-TNF agents. Given this, the top two choices of biological drugs for this patient would be Upadacitinib and Ustekinumab.

1. Upadacitinib:
   - Advantages: Upadacitinib has been found to be the most efficacious therapy for moderately to severely active UC. It has shown efficacy in achieving clinical response, clinical remission, and endoscopic response over 1 year for moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis patients.
   - Disadvantages: Despite its efficacy, Upadacitinib has been ranked last in terms of safety due to the total number of adverse events. It also has limitations including limited efficacy in some patients, primary non-response, secondary loss of response, and immunogenicity.

2. Ustekinumab:
   - Advantages: Ustekinumab has been ranked highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF antagonists for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement. It is also ranked first in terms of safety, indicating fewer adverse events compared to other drugs.
   - Disadvantages: The efficacy of Ustekinumab may not be as high as Upadacitinib. Additionally, like other biologics, it may have limitations including limited efficacy in some patients, primary non-response, secondary loss of response, and immunogenicity.

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

Discussion 
We reviewed available efficacy and safety data from RCTs 
of biologics and small molecule drugs (approved or in a 
late stage of development) for induction and maintenance 
treatment of patients with moderate-to-severe ulcerative 
colitis. All small molecule drugs and approved biologics, 
except filgotinib 100 mg, were significantly better than 
placebo in terms of inducing clinical remission and 
endoscopic improvement. A novel finding of this study 
was that upadacitinib ranked highest for the induction of 
clinical remission and endoscopic improvement, and 
was notably superior for these outcomes to all other 
interventions in our network meta-analysis. Infliximab 
ranked second for both outcomes. Regarding safety, 
vedolizumab was still ranked as the safest drug in 
terms of adverse events and serious adverse events, as 
previously 
observed

text: Burr et al. 
 
27 of 45 
DISCUSSION 
We conducted a contemporaneous systematic review and network meta-analysis of 
biological therapies and small molecules for moderate to severely active UC. This has 
incorporated data from 28 RCTs and over 12,500 patients. Overall, in terms of clinical 
remission and clinical response at 6 to 14 weeks, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked first in all 
patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these 
drugs. In terms of endoscopic improvement infliximab 10mg/kg ranked first, followed by 
upadacitinib 45mg o.d., and infliximab 5mg/kg. However, again upadacitinib 45mg o.d. 
ranked first in patients previously exposed to anti-TNF-α therapies, and in patients who were 
anti-TNF-α naïve. In terms of safety, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked last for total number of 
adverse events, and ustekinumab 130mg first. However, none of the drugs studied were more

title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1.0

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.
2180 Singh et al
Clinical Gastroenterology and Hepatology Vol. 18, No. 10
source10:
title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 3.0

text: Burr et al. 
 
3 of 45 
ABSTRACT 
Objective: Biological therapies and small molecules continue to be evaluated in moderate to 
severely active ulcerative colitis, but are often studied in placebo-controlled trials, meaning 
their relative efficacy and safety is unknown. We examined this in a network meta-analysis.  
Design: We searched the literature to October 2021 to identify eligible trials. We judged 
efficacy using clinical remission, endoscopic improvement, or clinical response, and 
according to previous exposure or non-exposure to anti-tumour necrosis factor (TNF)-α 
therapy. We also assessed safety. We used a random effects model and reported data as 
pooled relative risks (RRs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs). Interventions were ranked 
according to their P-score. 
Results: We identified 28 trials (12,504 patients). Based on failure to achieve clinical 
remission, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked first versus placebo (RR = 0.73; 95% CI 0.68-0.80,

Human: question
pro1: Ustekinumab is a good option for this patient as it is indicated for both ulcerative colitis and rheumatoid arthritis. It can help manage both conditions simultaneously, reducing the number of medications the patient needs to take. Ustekinumab works by blocking interleukin-12 and interleukin-23, which are involved in the inflammatory and immune responses.
cons1: Possible side effects of Ustekinumab include upper respiratory infections, headache, and fatigue. There is also a risk of serious infections, malignancies, and hypersensitivity reactions. It may not be as effective in patients who have failed anti-TNF therapy.
pro2: TNF inhibitors, such as Infliximab or Adalimumab, can be effective in treating both ulcerative colitis and rheumatoid arthritis. They work by blocking the action of tumor necrosis factor-alpha, a substance in the body that causes inflammation.
cons2: TNF inhibitors can increase the risk of serious infections, including tuberculosis and fungal infections. Other side effects can include injection site reactions, nausea, and headaches. They may also increase the risk of certain types of cancer, including lymphoma.

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates

maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Vedolizumab and Adalimumab.

1. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets the gut and has less systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It can be administered as an intravenous infusion every 8 weeks after the initial loading doses, which may be more convenient for some patients.
   - Disadvantages: The main disadvantage of Vedolizumab is that it requires intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient for some patients. Additionally, it may take several weeks to months to see the full effect of the drug.

2. Adalimumab:
   - Advantages: Adalimumab is a TNF-alpha inhibitor that has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It can be self-administered as a subcutaneous injection, which may be more convenient for patients who prefer to avoid hospital visits.
   - Disadvantages: Some patients may experience injection site reactions. Additionally, as with all immunosuppressants, there is a risk of serious infections and potential for increased risk of malignancies.

Please note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances and preferences, and in consultation with their healthcare provider.

prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be:

1. Infliximab
2. Upadacitinib

Infliximab:
- Advantages: Infliximab has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also ranked highest in biologic-naïve patients for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement.
- Disadvantages: Infliximab has potential side effects including risk of serious infections, lymphoma, and other malignancies. It also has the potential for primary non-response or secondary loss of response.

Upadacitinib:
- Advantages: Upadacitinib may be the most efficacious therapy for moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis based on ITT analyses, with similar safety across advanced therapies. It may be more efficacious than other advanced therapies at achieving clinical response, clinical remission, and endoscopic response over 1 year.
- Disadvantages: The safety profile of upadacitinib is still being evaluated, and it may have potential side effects including serious infections, malignancies, and thrombosis. It also requires regular monitoring for changes in blood counts, liver enzymes, and cholesterol levels.

Please note that the choice of therapy should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances, including their overall health, comorbidities, and preferences.

source8:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1.0

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.
2180 Singh et al

source10:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 0.0

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, she is a patient under maintenance who is not responding to azathioprine therapy. Considering her age and the severity of her ulcerative colitis, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Infliximab and Vedolizumab.

1. Infliximab:
   - Advantages: Infliximab has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also beneficial for patients who have not responded to conventional therapy.
   - Disadvantages: Infliximab can cause serious infections and allergic reactions. It may also increase the risk of certain types of cancer.

2. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets the gut and spares the rest of the body from immunosuppression. This can result in fewer side effects compared to other treatments.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may take longer to work compared to other treatments. It can also cause side effects such as headache, joint pain, nausea, and fever.

It's important to note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances and preferences. The patient should also be closely monitored for any side effects during the treatment.

source8:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1.0

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.
2180 Singh et al
Clinical Gastroenterology and Hepatology Vol. 18, No. 10

title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 5.0

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

gt_reason: Low serum albumin associated with poorer resonse to anti-TNFs (especially Infliximab)
prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================

- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Infliximab and Adalimumab. 

1. Infliximab:
   - Advantages: Infliximab has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also beneficial for patients with low albumin levels, as it can help reduce inflammation and improve nutritional status.
   - Disadvantages: Infliximab can cause serious side effects, including infections, heart failure, and a higher risk of lymphoma. It also requires intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient for some patients.

2. Adalimumab:
   - Advantages: Adalimumab is also effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and can be administered subcutaneously, which may be more convenient for some patients. It may also be a good option for patients who have not responded to or cannot tolerate Infliximab.
   - Disadvantages: Adalimumab can also cause serious side effects, including infections, heart failure, and a higher risk of lymphoma. It may not be as effective as Infliximab in patients with low albumin levels.

Please note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's overall health, preferences, and potential for side effects. Regular monitoring is necessary to assess the effectiveness and safety of the treatment.

question: 42 year-old woman with severe ulcerative colitis and rare fistulating disease
gt_reason: No real data on ulcerative colitis - related fistula
prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs for her severe ulcerative colitis and rare fistulating disease would be Infliximab and Adalimumab. 

1. Infliximab:
   - Advantages: Infliximab is a potent anti-TNF agent that has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also particularly effective in treating fistulating diseases, which the patient has.
   - Disadvantages: Infliximab can cause serious side effects, including infections (such as tuberculosis), heart failure, and potentially fatal lymphomas and other cancers. It can also cause infusion reactions, which can be severe.

2. Adalimumab:
   - Advantages: Adalimumab is another anti-TNF agent that has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is administered via subcutaneous injection, which some patients may find more convenient than the intravenous infusion required for infliximab.
   - Disadvantages: Like infliximab, adalimumab can cause serious side effects, including infections, heart failure, and potentially fatal lymphomas and other cancers. It can also cause injection site reactions.

It's important to note that the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's specific circumstances, including her overall health, the severity of her disease, her personal preferences, and her response to previous treatments.

disabling condition that is clinically characterised 
by bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and tenesmus.1 
Ulcerative colitis most commonly presents during the 
third and fifth decades of life, and is associated with an 
impaired health-related quality of life and considerable 
economic burden.2,3
Nearly 20 years ago, the advent of anti-tumour necrosis 
factor biologics (eg, infliximab, adalimumab, and 
golimumab) revolutionised therapeutics for ulcerative 
colitis, enabling better disease control in terms of 
increasing the rates of mucosal healing, deep remission, 
and corticosteroid-free remission, and improving quality 
of life. Biologics with other targets were later approved 
for the treatment of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis,

question: 68 year-old man with extensive moderate to severe ulcerative colitis who has prostate cancer which has been treated 5 years ago.
gt_reason: Anti-TNFs and JAK inhs have associations/concerns with malignancies
prompt:
System: 
You are a physician assistant giving advice on treatment for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC).
Make reference to the CONTEXT given to assess the scenario. If you do not know the answer. just say that "I don't know", don't try to make up an answer.
=================================
TASK: ANALYSE the given patient profile based on given query based on one of the following criteria:
- Whether treated patient is new patient or patient under maintenance
- Prior response to Infliximab
- Prior failure to Anti-TNF agents
- Prior failure to Vedolizumab
- Age
- Pregnancy
- Extraintestinale manifestations
- Pouchitis

FINALLY RETURN up to 2 TOP choices of biological drugs given patient profile. Explain the PROS and CONS of the 2 choices.
=================================
OUTPUT INSTRUCTIONS:
Output your answer as a list of JSON objects with keys: drug_name, advantages, disadvantages.
=================================
CONTEXT:
summaries
=================================

Human: question
raw_answer:
Based on the patient's profile, the top two choices of biological drugs would be Vedolizumab and Ustekinumab. 

1. Vedolizumab:
   - Advantages: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets inflammation in the gut, reducing systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
   - Disadvantages: Vedolizumab may take longer to show effects compared to other biologics. It also requires intravenous administration, which can be inconvenient for some patients. There is also a risk of infusion-related reactions.

2. Ustekinumab:
   - Advantages: Ustekinumab has been shown to be effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It can be administered subcutaneously after the initial intravenous dose, which can be more convenient for the patient.
   - Disadvantages: Ustekinumab may increase the risk of infections. It may also not be as effective in patients who have previously failed anti-TNF therapy.

It's important to note that the patient's age and history of prostate cancer should be taken into consideration when choosing a treatment. Both Vedolizumab and Ustekinumab have been associated with a slight increase in the risk of infections, which could potentially be more serious in older patients or those with a history of cancer. The patient's overall health status and preferences should also be considered in the decision-making process.

source5:
title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 5.0

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

title: Efficacy of biological therapies and small molecules in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis: systematic review and network meta-analysis

filename: gutjnl-2021-326390R2 CLEAN.pdf

page: 5.0

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.

text: Burr et al. 
 
7 of 45 
INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

source3:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1.0

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.
2180 Singh et al
Clinical Gastroenterology and Hepatology Vol. 18, No. 10

source5:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 0.0

text: (prior exposure to tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for treatment of moder-
ate to severely active ulcerative colitis in a systematic review and network meta-analysis.
METHODS:
We searched publication databases through September 30, 2019, for randomized trials of
adults with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis treated with TNF antagonists, vedolizumab,
tofacitinib, or ustekinumab, as ﬁrst-line or second-line agents, compared with placebo or
another active agent. Efﬁcacy outcomes were induction and maintenance of remission and
endoscopic improvement; safety outcomes were serious adverse events and infections. We
performed a ﬁxed-effects network meta-analysis using the frequentist approach, and calculated
odds ratios (ORs) and 95% CI values. Agents were ranked using surface under the cumulative
ranking (SUCRA) probabilities. Overall quality of evidence was rated using GRADE (Grading of
Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluation).
RESULTS:

text: vs adalimumab: OR, 11.05; 95% CI, 1.79–68.41; moderate CE). Vedolizumab had the lowest risk
of infections (SUCRA, 0.81), followed by ustekinumab (SUCRA, 0.63) in maintenance trials.
CONCLUSIONS:
In a systematic review and network meta-analysis, we found inﬂiximab to be ranked highest in
biologic-naïve patients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked highest in patients with
prior exposure to TNF antagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic improvement in
patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision making with greater conﬁdence.

source5:
title: First- and Second-Line Pharmacotherapies for Patients With Moderate to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis: An Updated Network Meta-Analysis

filename: PIIS1542356520300446.pdf

page: 1.0

text: What You Need to Know
Background
A systematic review and network meta-analysis is
needed to compare efﬁcacy and safety of ﬁrst-line
(biologic-naïve) and second-line (prior exposure to
tumor necrosis factor [TNF] antagonists) agents for
treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis.
Findings
Inﬂiximab was ranked highest in biologic-naïve pa-
tients, and ustekinumab and tofacitinib were ranked
highest in patients with prior exposure to TNF an-
tagonists, for induction of remission and endoscopic
improvement. More trials of direct comparisons are
needed to inform clinical decision-making with
greater conﬁdence.
Implications for patient care
Patients with moderate to severely active ulcerative
colitis should receive inﬂiximab or vedolizumab as
ﬁrst-line therapy, or ustekinumab or tofacitinib if
they have prior exposure to TNF antagonists.

Clinical Gastroenterology and Hepatology Vol. 18, No. 10

INTRODUCTION 
  Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the bowel that causes 
continuous mucosal inflammation commencing in the rectum and extending proximally for a 
variable extent.[1] It is estimated that UC affects 2.5 million people in Europe,[2] and the 
disease follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent flares of disease activity, 
some of which may be moderate to severe. Management of these is medical, for the most 
part, with surgery reserved for patients with refractory disease. Although 5-aminosalicylates 
(5-ASAs) are efficacious for mild to moderate disease activity,[3-6] more severe flares are 
usually treated with corticosteroids.[7] However, these have potentially serious adverse 
effects and a substantial proportion of patients may become either dependent on them to 
maintain remission,[8] or refractory to them.[9] As a result, over the last 20 years novel

Human: question
pro1: Vedolizumab is a gut-selective immunosuppressant, meaning it specifically targets the gut and has less systemic side effects. It has been shown to be effective in inducing and maintaining remission in moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It is also a good option for patients who have failed or are intolerant to TNF inhibitors.
cons1: Vedolizumab may take longer to work compared to other biologics. It is administered via intravenous infusion, which may be inconvenient for some patients. Side effects can include headache, joint pain, nausea, and fever. Serious side effects can include infections and liver problems.
pro2: Ustekinumab is effective in treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis and has a good safety profile. It is also beneficial for patients with extraintestinal manifestations such as psoriasis or psoriatic arthritis, which may be relevant given the patient's optic neuritis.
cons2: Ustekinumab requires an initial intravenous infusion followed by subcutaneous injections, which may be inconvenient for some patients. Side effects can include upper respiratory infections, headache, and fatigue. There is also a risk of serious infections and potential for developing certain types of cancer.

text: Burr et al. 
 
5 of 45 
STUDY HIGHLIGHTS 
 
What is already known about this subject 
• Ulcerative colitis (UC) follows a relapsing and remitting course, with intermittent 
flares of disease activity, some of which may be moderate to severe. 
• These are usually treated with corticosteroids, which have potentially serious adverse 
effects, so biological therapies and small molecules have been developed and licensed 
for this indication.  
• Although previous network meta-analyses have compared their efficacy and safety, 
this is a rapidly moving field, and there are already several newer drugs that have 
shown efficacy in phase III clinical trials that were not considered in these. 
 
What are the new findings 
• In terms of clinical remission and clinical response, upadacitinib 45mg o.d. ranked 
first in all patients, in patients previously exposed to anti-tumour necrosis factor 
(TNF)-α therapies, and in patients naïve to these drugs.
